title: The Wall Street fee parade grinds to a halt
text:
One scoop to start: Aston Martin is closing in on a deal to raise significantly more than £500mn by bringing in Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund as a significant shareholder and holding a rights issue for current investors, according to two people.

In today's newsletter:

  • Bankers face the music

  • Crypto finally has its day in court 

  • Investors sour on China's VC scene

Bad vibes grip Wall Street 

In 2021, the big fear for bank chieftains such as Goldman's David Solomon was the unrest among junior bankers as they churned out an epic pipeline of initial public offerings, mega mergers and blank cheque deals.

As he prepares for DJ season in the Hamptons, Solomon doesn't have to worry about another leaked PowerPoint presentation from employees complaining about burnout.

A bigger issue has emerged that will strike enough fear into bankers to put them back in line.

Business on Wall Street has dried up amid a sharp sell-off in stocks, surging inflation and fast rising interest rates.

On Thursday, JPMorgan Chase issued a warning sign that a golden age for deals has ended. The New York group's investment banking revenues of $1.4bn were 55 per cent below analyst forecasts.

The miss, combined with a suspension of share buybacks, sent JPMorgan's stock lower and into a 30 per cent drawdown for the year, the FT's Joshua Franklin and Imani Moise report.

The biggest issue was a slowdown in IPOs. Equity underwriting fees were off 77 per cent, while debt underwriting fees were down by more than half as capital markets seized up.

Even worse may be the hangover from the era of cheap money as the Federal Reserve quickly raises interest rates.

JPMorgan took a $257mn writedown from bridge loans and unfunded leveraged buyout financing commitments it is trying to distribute.

Morgan Stanley's investment banking revenues fell 55 per cent, slightly less than JPMorgan. A surprise was its $200mn settlement over bankers' use of personal devices and poor record keeping. (JPMorgan also paid that amount in fines to resolve a similar case.)

JPMorgan chief Jamie Dimon believes he sidestepped the worst of it.

“Our bridge book is smaller than it was because we priced ourselves out of the market and that was a good thing because a lot of people lost a lot of money there and we lost a little,” he said, referring to now troubled financings for large leveraged buyouts.

Credit Suisse, Bank of America and Goldman are figuring out how to syndicate debt for Elliott Management and Vista Equity's $16.5bn buyout of Citrix, a financing JPMorgan skipped. It also passed on 2022's biggest potential debacle, Elon Musk's $44bn buyout of Twitter, a deal the mercurial billionaire is now trying to terminate.

Goldman will report earnings on Monday. The early warnings are enough to kill whatever vibe Solomon and his bankers had going into the weekend.

Celsius heats up the restructuring world

Customers hoping to reach Celsius Network had to dial 1-866-HODL-NOW to get through to the now-failed crypto lender.

For DD readers wilfully ignorant of the speculative asset class, the term “HODL” was a typo for “hold” made by a trader during one of crypto's many plunges. It has since morphed into the industry's mantra, “hold on for dear life”.

Over the past month, lenders such as Celsius and Voyager Digital have lived up to the rallying cry by freezing customer assets to stem runs by depositors amid a crypto sell-off. Unfortunately, that couldn't save either from bankruptcy.

On Wednesday, Celsius followed in Voyager's footsteps and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, DD's Antoine Gara and the FT's Kadhim Shubber and Joshua Oliver reported. The lender's first-day declaration showed a $1.2bn financial hole.

The bankruptcies indicate that there is a nascent business taking shape on Wall Street. Restructuring advisers are finding good work unwinding failed crypto trading groups.

Investment bank Moelis & Co is advising Voyager, while Berkeley Research Group is its restructuring adviser.

Centerview Partners is advising Celsius, while Alvarez & Marsal, the consultancy famed for unwinding Lehman Brothers, is its restructuring adviser.

Kirkland & Ellis has been hired by both companies as a legal adviser.

It's a good bet more restructurings are in store. Crypto exchange FTX lent emergency cash to BlockFi, but its coffers are limited.

The restructurings also offer surprising career opportunities. David Barse, the former chief executive of Third Avenue Management, who left the investment firm as his debt fund suspended investor withdrawals, has been named a director of Celsius.

Regardless, there's a grim reality for true believers of “DeFi”, or crypto's promise to supplant the traditional financial services industry.

It is establishment hands like the judges and advisers who waded through the mess of the 2008 financial crisis who are now the HODLers' best hope. Lex notes they face many novel challenges.

A flashing red warning sign for venture firms in China

China funds are struggling to raise new capital as institutional investors begin to rethink locking up their cash in the country, wary of Beijing's regulatory crackdowns and growing geopolitical risk.

Venture capital investors Genesis Capital, Xiang He Capital and Centurium, which had cumulatively raised billions of dollars for prior funds, are facing drawn out fundraisings and other challenges in closing new rounds, the FT reports.

Centurium's first fund signed up 40 American investors for $1.9bn in 2019. Its second fund this year took 12 months to raise just $250mn from six US investors.

Even Philippe Laffont's Coatue Management, one of the biggest “Tiger cubs”, has struggled to pull in all the capital it aimed to raise for China investments. Its inaugural China-heavy Asia fund has raised less than $1bn after targeting $1.5bn-$2bn when starting to pitch investors last August.

Western investors such as pensions and endowments are worried.

John Bradley, the head of private equity investments at Florida's pension fund, summed up some of the fears in a meeting last month. “The risk part of the equation [for China] has probably increased exponentially and so it's led us to back off.”

The rethink marks a sharp turn of fortunes for China's VC community and the start-ups they seed, after a decade of foreign money spawned thousands of fund managers and incubated today's tech titans like Alibaba, TikTok owner ByteDance and food delivery group Meituan.

China-focused PE and VC fundraising was down 94 per cent in the first half of 2022.  

However, recent announcements from Sequoia Capital China and Qiming Venture Partners signal investors with the best records can still raise money — and may benefit from a flight to quality. The two VC groups have closed more than $10bn since July 1.

Job moves

  • Alphabet has added Marty Chavez, the former chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs and the current vice-chair of Sixth Street to its board of directors. Chavez will replace board director Robin Washington on the tech company's audit and compliance committees. Washington will continue as a director, chairing Alphabet's leadership development, inclusion and compensation committees.

  • James Gill has been named head of financial institutions investment banking for Europe, the Middle East and Africa at Bank of America. He joined the bank in London from Prudential in 2020.  

  • Engine maker Cummins said it has named Jennifer Rumsey as its chief executive. She replaces Tom Linebarger, who will remain as chair.

Smart reads

Debit Suisse The latest FT Film to premiere looks at what went wrong and what comes next for Credit Suisse, one of Switzerland's most important institutions. Can the bank win back the trust it has lost following multiple scandals?

Slingin' equities The business of block trading is under close regulatory scrutiny. A former senior capital markets banker writes for FT Alphaville about how big the effect of a crackdown would be on this lucrative corner of investment banking.

Succession in shambles Bob Iger envisioned a smooth succession as he handed Disney off to his close friend and apprentice, Bob Chapek, in early 2020. But the pandemic and a sharp turn in the company's fortunes quickly had Iger regretting “one of his worst business decisions”, according to this Business Insider report.

News round-up

Stripe cuts internal valuation by 28 per cent (WSJ)

Deutsche Bank and UBS get rare lifeline on buyout debt (Bloomberg)

SEC scrutinises Musk tweet over $44bn Twitter takeover bid (FT)

Deutsche Telekom to sell majority stake in towers business (FT + Lex)

Alibaba cuts a third of deals team staff after regulatory crackdown-sources (Reuters)

Playtech takeover battle fizzles out without a deal (FT)

Saipem gets the wrong end of the stick (FT)

Lenders take control of Vue cinema chain in £1bn restructuring (FT)
